etymology.description: Phonetic: 厂 + semantic: 彣 (“variegated; literary talent”).
etymology.interpretation: Meaning is guided by 彣, which evokes patterned writing and literary talent, fitting the sense of an accomplished person. The sound was borrowed from 厂 in Old Chinese, and later evolved to yàn in modern Mandarin while the talent-related meaning persisted.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 彥 by omitting the 彡 ornament from the semantic element 彣, reducing strokes while retaining the core structure and function.

examples.chinese: 他是本校的英彦，屡获大奖。(他是本校的英彥，屢獲大獎。)
examples.pinyin: Tā shì běnxiào de yīngyàn, lǚ huò dàjiǎng.
examples.english: He is the outstanding talent of our school, winning many major awards.

examples.chinese: 这位青年被誉为科技界的俊彦。(這位青年被譽為科技界的俊彥。)
examples.pinyin: Zhè wèi qīngnián bèi yùwéi kējìjiè de jùnyàn.
examples.english: This young man is hailed as a leading talent in the tech world.
